In $\triangle ABC$, prove that $a(\sin B - \sin C) + b(\sin C - \sin A) + c(\sin A - \sin B) = 0$. (Board 2024)
answer: Using the sine rule, $a = k\sin A, b = k\sin B, c = k\sin C$. Substituting these into the LHS gives $k\sin A(\sin B - \sin C) + k\sin B(\sin C - \sin A) + k\sin C(\sin A - \sin B)$. Expanding this expression results in all terms cancelling out, proving the identity.
